title: 1Â  Why Use a Cluster?
text:
1.2 Introduction to High-Performance Computing (HPC)
Many research problems that require computing power often outgrow the capabilities of a standard desktop or laptop. HPC systems, typically structured as clusters of interconnected computers, provide a way to solve these problems efficiently. Letâ€™s explore why HPC is useful with a few examples.

1.2.1 When Do You Need More Than a Laptop?
Here are some common scenarios where an HPC system is beneficial:

1.2.1.1 Example 1: Running Many Independent Simulations (Parallel Computing)
A statistics student wants to validate a model by running it 1000 times. - Problem: Each run takes an hour. Running them sequentially on a laptop would take over a month. - Solution: Since each run is independent, they can be executed simultaneously on different machines (parallel computing), reducing the total runtime significantly.


1.2.1.2 Example 2: Analyzing Large Datasets (Memory Constraints)
A genomics researcher needs to process a dataset 10 times larger than before. - Problem: The dataset is too large to even open on a standard computer. - Solution: An HPC system with more memory (RAM) can handle large datasets and perform the necessary calculations without crashing.


1.2.1.3 Example 3: Complex Simulations (Distributed Computing)
An engineer using fluid dynamics simulations moves from 2D to 3D modeling. - Problem: The computation time has more than tripled. - Solution: HPC allows parallel processing where different parts of the simulation run simultaneously, communicating only when necessary, to converge on a final result efficiently.



1.2.2 What is an HPC System?
An HPC system is a cluster of computers working together, enabling researchers to: - Run tasks in parallel (splitting workloads across multiple processors). - Access more memory to handle large datasets. - Speed up complex computations by distributing tasks efficiently.

title: 1Â  Why Use a Cluster?
section: 1.3 Have You Used a Server Before?
text:
1.3 Have You Used a Server Before?
Even if youâ€™ve never used an HPC system, you likely interact with remote servers daily. Here are some examples:

1.3.1 Everyday Examples of Remote Computing

Checking Email

Your device contacts a remote email server to send and receive messages.
Many users access the same server, making it a shared resource.

Searching Online

When you search for a term, a remote server processes your request against a massive database.
The indexing of websites is done in parallel using multiple servers.

Finding Directions on a Map

Your request for a route is processed by a remote system that calculates the best path based on various metrics.
Large-scale calculations like this are distributed across multiple machines.




1.3.2 Serial vs.Â Parallel Processing in Daily Life

Serial Processing: Your laptop connects to a single email server to download your messages.
Parallel Processing: Large-scale search engines use thousands of servers working together to provide instant search results.

title: 1Â  Why Use a Cluster?
text:
1.4 Conclusion
HPC systems are powerful tools that enable faster, more efficient computing for research and data-intensive applications. By leveraging parallel computing, distributed resources, and enhanced memory, researchers can tackle problems that would be impossible on standard computers.

4.1 ğŸ“Œ Generate an SSH Key Pair
Run this command in your terminal:
ssh-keygen -a 100 -t ed25519 -f ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
ğŸ”¹ When prompted for a passphrase, enter a secure password (or leave it empty for no password).
ğŸ”¹ If successful, your SSH key pair is stored in:
- ~/.ssh/id_ed25519 (private key) â€“ DO NOT SHARE!
- ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub (public key) â€“ This goes to the HPC cluster.
ğŸ’¡ For older systems: If ed25519 is unavailable, use RSA instead:

title: 2Â  Connecting to Remote HPC Systems
section: 4.2 ğŸ“‚ Step 4: Copy Your Public Key to the HPC Cluster
text:
4.2 ğŸ“‚ Step 4: Copy Your Public Key to the HPC Cluster
Now, send your public key to the HPC system:
scp ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub username@hpc-cluster-address:~/
Then, log into the cluster using your password-based SSH and install the key:
ssh username@hpc-cluster-address
mkdir -p ~/.ssh
cat ~/id_ed25519.pub >> ~/.ssh/authorized_keys
chmod 600 ~/.ssh/authorized_keys
Now, logout and try reconnecting:
exit
ssh username@hpc-cluster-address
ğŸš€ If everything is set up correctly, you should log in without entering a password!
